items.longDescription:
The front of the T-shirt is embroidered with a design depicting Doraemon with the glass pyramid, the main entrance of the museum. The back of the T-shirt features an original illustration of Doraemon and Nobita visiting the Louvre at night.

Doraemon meets the Louvre

Doraemon, Japans popular character created by FujikoFFujio, and his friends visits the Louvre, enjoying its art and even stepping into the world of its masterpieces. Enjoy this unique UT collection, where you can journey with Doraemon and his friends through the timeless and radiant world of art that continues to shine across space and time.

Inspired by: Louvre Pyramid I.M. Pei
Fujiko-Pro, Shogakukan, TV-Asahi, Shin-ei, and ADK

items.longDescription:
NY POP ART

UT has long partnered with pop art pioneers, including Andy Warhol, Keith Haring, and Jean-Michel Basquiat. These legendary artists have left behind various works that make art more accessible and enjoyable for people. Experience the joy of wearing pop art that is loved across generations.

Keith Haring
A key figure in New Yorks East Village scene in the late 1970s and 80s, American artist Keith Harings artwork populated not only art galleries, but also the citys subways, streets, and sidewalks. His work often combined an iconographic vocabulary, including hearts, flying saucers, winged figures, and a crawling radiant baby, with abstract marks and patterning.

Keith Haring Foundation. Licensed by Artestar, New York.

items.longDescription:
MANGA curation

Featuring Berserk, Parasyte, and Uzumaki, which have long garnered a large following due to their worldview, stories, and artistry, this is a collection of titles selected by UT from the perspective of graphic T-shirts that bring the profound world of MANGA to life.

Hitoshi Iwaaki was born in Tokyo 1960.He debuted in 1985 with Gomi no Umi, which was published in the Morning Open supplement.
In 1993, he won the 17th Kodansha Manga Award for Parasyte, serialized in Afternoon.His representative works include Parasyte, Tanabata no Kuni and Heureka.
He is currently serializing Historie in Afternoon.It won the grand prize in the manga division of the 14th Japan Media Arts Festival and the 16th Osamu Tezuka Cultural Prize Manga Grand Prize.

Hitoshi Iwaaki/KODANSHA Ltd.

items.longDescription:
MANGA curation

Featuring Berserk, Parasyte, and Uzumaki, which have long garnered a large following due to their worldview, stories, and artistry, this is a collection of titles selected by UT from the perspective of graphic T-shirts that bring the profound world of MANGA to life.

Junji Ito was born on July 31st, 1963 in Nakatsugawa, Gifu Prefecture.After graduating from high school, he entered dental technician school and entered the work force. However, when the Monthly Halloween (Asahi Sonorama) newcomer manga award the Umezu Award was established, he submitted his work with the single-minded desire to have it read by Kazuo Umezu.
In 1986, he received an honorable mention for his contribution Tomie. This was his debut work and became his best-known title.Three years later, he quit his job as a dental technician to concentrate on his manga career.In 1998, he began serializing Uzumaki in Weekly Big Comic Spirits (Shogakukan).
Since then, he has continued to publish one-of-a-kind works.
He has won The Will Eisner Comic Industry Award, one of the world's most prestigious awards for manga artists, four times in total, and in 2023 received the Special Honors Award at the Angoulme International Manga Festival in France, as well as the Inkpot Award at San Diego Comic-Con in the USA.

Junji ITO/Shogakukan

Keith Haring
A key figure in New Yorks East Village scene in the late 1970s and 80s, American artist Keith Harings artwork populated not only art galleries, but also the citys subways, streets, and sidewalks. His work often combined an iconographic vocabulary, including hearts, flying saucers, winged figures, and a crawling radiant baby, with abstract marks and patterning.

Keith Haring Foundation. Licensed by Artestar, New York.
